Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=WINDOWS-1252;
	format=flowed

 From what you describe, it is hard to know where the problem is.  Maybe 
t=
he equilibrium solver is having trouble converging.  You can tell it 
to us=
e the new solver by giving a third non-zero parameter to 
equilibrate, e.g.=
:

equilibrate(gas, 'TP', 1)

If the third paramter is missing or zero, the=
 old solver will be used, 
which is faster but less stable than the new one=
.  Equilibrium problem 
usually arise from specifying very hard initial con=
ditions, like an 
exactly stoichiometric fuel/air mixture at 300 K. Neverth=
eless, the new 
solver should handle these cases.

Other than that, you wil=
l need to do some debugging to isolate the 
problem.  Since the transport d=
emo works, you can start with it and 
modify it one line at a time until it=
 looks like your m-file that 
fails. In that way, you should be able to tra=
ck down exactly what 
change causes failure.  If it is not due to an initia=
l condition and 
seems to be something in Cantera, then see how small an m-=
file you can 
create that still fails by removing extraneous lines.  For ex=
ample, 
does it fail if you only do equillibrium? Or do you need to compute=
 
transport propertiess for it to fail?

Once you have isolated the problem=
, send the short m-file to me, and I 
can see if it fails for me too, and s=
ee what the problem is.

=

transport1.m in the MATLAB/demos and it works fine. But when I run my

> of er=
ror messages. Sometimes, it runs and gives me a reasonable result,
> someti=
mes, it runs and gives Nan for all transport properties, 
> sometimes
> it =
does not run and gives error message such as 'segmentation error'.
> Note t=
hat the code itself is the same. I just try run different times.
> It gives=
 me different things. I guess it is related to memory. Any help
> to fix th=
is will be highly appreciated. Thanks!
>
>
> I have not received any reply.=
 My colleague had the similar problem. 
> We are in the process to incopora=
te Cantera into our system modleing 
> using Matlab. One of my colleague do=
es NOT has problem because he has 
> the older version of Cantera. We need =
a solution to fix the problem. 
> Could you please look into this? Should w=
e download the older version 
> of Cantera? And which version should we use=
?
>
> Thanks again!
>

Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/enriched;
	charset=WINDOWS-1252

From what you describe, it is hard to know where the problem is. 
Maybe the=
 equilibrium solver is having trouble converging.  You can
tell it to use t=
he new solver by giving a third non-zero parameter to
equilibrate, e.g.:


=
equilibrate(gas, 'TP', 1)


If the third paramter is missing or zero, the o=
ld solver will be used,
which is faster but less stable than the new one.  =
Equilibrium problem
usually arise from specifying very hard initial conditi=
ons, like an
exactly stoichiometric fuel/air mixture at 300 K. Nevertheless=
, the
new solver should handle these cases. 


Other than that, you will ne=
ed to do some debugging to isolate the
problem.  Since the transport demo w=
orks, you can start with it and
modify it one line at a time until it looks=
 like your m-file that
fails. In that way, you should be able to track down=
 exactly what
change causes failure.  If it is not due to an initial condit=
ion and
seems to be something in Cantera, then see how small an m-file you =
can
create that still fails by removing extraneous lines.  For example,
doe=
s it fail if you only do equillibrium? Or do you need to compute
transport =
propertiess for it to fail? 


Once you have isolated the problem, send the=
 short m-file to me, and I
can see if it fails for me too, and see what the=
 problem is.
